testimony:
Good morning everybody.  Today we will be dealing with the application of Mr Phillip Faizel Malefane.
	Before we commence I'll just introduce the panel to you.  On my right is Advocate John Motata, he is an Advocate from Johannesburg and on my left is Advocate Francis Bosman and advocate from Cape Town and I am Selwyn Miller a judge from the High Court from the Eastern Cape, in particular the Transkei Division of the High Court.
	I'll just ask the legal representatives kindly to place their names on record.
Thank you Mr Chairperson and Honourable Members of the Committee, my name is Lungelo Mbandazayo, I'm representing the applicant in this matter.  Thank you Mr Chairperson.
Thank you Mr Chairman, Members of the Committee, I am J. M. Mpshe, for the TRC Amnesty in particular, thank you.

Thank you.  The proceedings will be simultaneously translated and if you want to receive the translation you've got to be in possession of one of these devices, they are available and you can hear a simultaneous translation by using this.  Mr Mbandazayo?
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Chairperson, my first witness is the applicant himself, Mr Malefane, he is a Sesotho speaking and may he be sworn in Mr Chairperson?
Thank you.  Mr Malefane do you wish to take the oath or do you wish to make an affirmation of the truth?

Thank you Mr Chairperson.
Mr Chairperson I will try and lead the applicant, I don't have an affidavit also for this matter.
	Mr Malefane, can you tell the Committee when did you join the PAC?
Where did you join the PAC?
Who recruited you to the PAC?
Could you spell that name please?

Who asked you to go to Lesotho in 1979 or were you recruited to go to Lesotho or did you go on your own.  Is there anybody who persuaded you to go to Lesotho or was it your own initiative, tell the Committee please?

I took a decision to go to Lesotho but at that time I was still in jail.  In 1979 I escaped from jail and then I went to Lesotho where I met the members of the PAC.  They influenced me to escape from jail and then after my escape I went to Lesotho.
Now how long did you stay in Lesotho?
I didn't stay a long time in Lesotho.  I went there in 1979 and then I came back in 1981 and I returned to South Africa.  I went there in 1979, on the 8th August 1981 I came back to South Africa.
What were you doing from 1979 to 1981, before you came back to South Africa, in Lesotho?
I was with the members of the PAC in Lesotho.  They were teaching about many things, they were giving me crash courses.
Now you said that you came back in August 1981, who gave you instructions to come back to the country or was it again your own initiative to come back?

I took a decision because in Lesotho I met
the children who I helped to come back to South Africa.  So I came back to South Africa because we needed money so that I could help these children.
Now you came back inside the country in August, what did you do on your arrival in the country?
Unfortunately I was arrested, I was arrested on the 12 August in 1981.
And I presume you were convicted?
That is correct Chairperson, I was convicted because they found two passports with me, Lesotho passport and South African passport and I was convicted for 108 days.
That is six months, 180 days in solitary confinement.
Okay, let me ask you this way.  At the time you left the country you escaped from prison and I presume you were serving a sentence at the time?
I think what Mr Mbandazayo is getting at, were you ever charged with escaping?
Was the sentence for escaping included in that 180 days that you got?

No Chairperson, it was not included.  After finishing 180 days I was taken to Barberton, I went there to finish my sentence for escaping from jail.
ADV. BOSMAN: Sorry, can we just get this clear, the 180 days, was that for a conviction, was that a sentence or were you detained under the security legislation?  I'm not quite sure on that?

At Motabele, they've written on a card and they said I will stay there for 180 days while the police were still investigating under the Security Act.
ADV. BOSMAN: Thank you.

Thank you Mr Chairperson.
	When were you released in prison for the offence for which you escaped from prison?
I was released on the 27th October 1986.
And after your release what were your activities?
After my release I went back to Lesotho.
Yes, how long did you stay in Lesotho?
I stayed in Lesotho from 1988 until 1990.
And I presume you came back from Lesotho?
Now what were your activities inside the country on your arrival from Lesotho?
I was a motor mechanic when I came back from Lesotho.

Okay now Mr Malefane, can you tell the Committee about this incident which happened on the 15th July 1991 which was at Stilfontein, which happened at Stilfontein.  Can you tell the Committee who came up with this idea and who was involved and what was the reason?

1990 I met Mabena.  It was at the ...(indistinct) welcome party.  He came to me to ask money for transport to go to Transkei so that he could go there and train at task force.  At that time I didn't have money with me so I took a decision that I should go out and get some money.  I met a Chris Msimeni, then I asked money from him.  I told him that there is an operation that I have to undertake.  He said to me he doesn't have money, he will tell me, so we met other people, he introduced me to those people in 1981 and then we went to Stilfontein Mines.
It was said you were introduced in 1981, I think it should have been 1991?
That is correct, Mr Chairperson, it should have been 1991.
Just one thing Mr Malefane, who is Chris Msimeni, who was he?
We grew up together but he was an MK member, we grew up together.
I met those guys who were three.  We went out to reconnoitre the Stilfontein mines, we went there twice.  For the third time when we went there, we were going to repossess.
Okay, can you tell the Committee who were these three guys, what was the names of the guys?
It was Bonginkosi Mchunu, Bango Ngubane, Eric Ntani.
Sorry, just repeat those three names please Mr Malefane?  I've got Bonginkosi Mchunu, Eric - what was his surname?
Now was it the only three of you to make your reconnaissance or it was the only three of you who went for this operation at Stilfontein?
I was the fourth one.  When we went there for reconnaissance we were four.
Now take us through, on the day of the incident, how many were you, how were you armed and where did you get the weapons?

On the day of the operation we were eight.
We had two AK47's, two revolvers and one pistol.  We driving three cars, the other one was a Chevrolet and two Fords, the other one was a bakkie and the other one was a sedan.  That was on the 15th July 1991.  We went to Stilfontein, our aim was to go there and repossess the money.
	We arrived there early in the morning, we waited there for the Fidelity Guard bakkie.  When it arrived we advanced and we told them to stand still.  They didn't do that and we started shooting and thereafter we also shot at them, one person was killed and the other one was injured.  We took the money, we put it into the bakkie, I was driving that bakkie and then from there, on our way I saw a white car flickering to us.  I didn't stop and then we advanced the cul de sac and I stopped there.  The other cars which were following me started shooting at that car.  I drove through the fence and then I ran away from the car.  I got injured while I was driving through the fence and I was arrested and taken to the police station and then from the police station I was taken to Sebong Hospital.

Now Mr Malefane, you already told the Committee the four of you went to do the reconnaissance but on the day in question you were eight, you have not told the Committee what was the names of the other four, extra four, the eight.  You have told us about four people, now the eight is now four you have not told the Committee of their names?
That's Eric Williams, David Nene, Johannes Mkhizi, Aaron Lekarapa.
Sorry just - what was Aaron's second name please?

That's Lekarapa.  L-e-k-a-r-a-p-a.
ADV. BOSMAN: Could you just give us Mkhizi's first name please?

Now Mr Malefane, you have told the Committee what happened and how did you plan and how did you carry out the operation at Stilfontein.  Now you are appearing before the Committee, you are asking the Committee - you are applying for amnesty.  Can you tell the Committee the reason why they should grant you amnesty for this operation?

I'm applying for amnesty because the money that we went to repossess was going to be used to help the task force.  It was going to be used for political purposes to train the task force s that we could disturb the councillors of the then government, that is why I'm asking for amnesty because this money was going to be used for the training of the task force.

That is all Mr Chairperson, no more questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MBANDAZAYO
Mr Mpshe do you have any questions to ask the witness?
Mr Malefane, if I heard you correctly, in your evidence in chief you spoke or make mention of children that you saw in Lesotho and decided to go and get money for them, is that correct?
Those were the youth who crossed over to Lesotho.
So when you crossed back out of Lesotho back into the country you were coming to get money to go and assist the youth in Lesotho, am I correct?
Now how did you hope to get the money to help the youth with?
I was going to get this money at all costs, I would use all the means to help me to get that money.  Either to go and ask money from my parents are to go and repossess it.
Is it correct then that this operation was intended to make you obtain to go back to Lesotho and help the youth there?
I didn't undertake any operation then, that was in 1979.  I didn't undertake any operation on my way back to South Africa.
Was this operation one of the means you were going to employ to get money for the children?
Are you talking about this operation?
Ja, the Stilfontein operation, was it was one of the means to aid the children?
So the money you were going to get from this operation was to be given to Lesotho children, the youth, let's call them youth?

No it was not going to be help these youth in Lesotho.  The money that we got from this operation was going to be given to be given Mabena because he asked me for money so that he could go and train the task force in Transkei, that is the operation we are talking about here.
You say you met Mabena in 1990 at Comrade Mothopeng's welcome.  For how long had you known Mabena?
It was the first time that I met Mabena at that welcome party.
You met him there for the first time and then he asked you for money to go to the Transkei?
Did he know that you were capable of getting money or did he suspect that you have money to give to anybody who needed?
We were introduced to one another and we held some discussions and from then he knew what I was doing at that time.  That is why he came to me because he knew of my activities.
Sorry Mr Mpshe.  Mr Malefane, what position did Mr Mabena hold, who was he?
He was a member of APLA.
Was he in the leadership of APLA?
He was a soldier.  He was just a soldier there.
Right, now before meeting Mabena and before this operation had you carried out other repossession operations before?
In 1979 I carried out an operation, I was also arrested after that operation and I was sentenced to six years imprisonment and thereafter I escaped from jail and went to Lesotho.
Yes, in this 1979 operation was money involved?
Now in your discussion with Mabena did you tell him that you are capable of getting money?
I told Mabena my ability to repair cars and my ability to help the youth in Lesotho, so I told him that if he needs some help he can come to me then I'll be able to help him.
And in the help that you promised him, you said you could get him money or did you say you could repair cars for him?
Any kind of help, either to repair a car or money, I would help him.

I see.
ADV. BOSMAN: Excuse me Mr Mpshe, I just want to clear up something here.  Did you say that you told him of your ability to obtain cars or to repair cars, I'm not sure if I have it right there?
I told him about my ability to repair the cars.
Did you hold any position of leadership in the PAC?
In 1979 we didn't have membership cards.

You see why I'm asking you this is because you - the answers you've been giving to me, the answers are trying to paint a picture of a person who was some form of leadership of doing things for the PAC.  Am I correct.
I was not a leader, I was just an activist, I was just helping.

Alright, if you have got the application form in front of you, look at page 1 of the application and look in particular paragraph 7(b).  I'll read for convenience, it says
"State capacity in which you served in the organisation, institution, body or liberation movement concerned, if applicable and membership number if any."
and you say there:
"To liberate the country."
Is being an activist not a capacity within an organisation or a foot soldier not a capacity within an organisation?

I thought that this refers to positions like presidents, at that time I was just an ordinary member, I didn't have any position in the organisation, I was just an activist, an active member in the organisation.  I didn't take it as a person who has a position in the organisation, I was just active in the organisation.
I see, is being an activist or a foot soldier not a capacity in an organisation, not leadership, capacity?
Yes that is correct, it's a capacity.
Why was it not written here you were an activist?
Yes I did not write, I agree that that's a mistake.
Turn to page 3, the paginated page 3.  Now was there - did any person in the leadership of PAC order or authorise this operation?

No one gave the go ahead for this operation.  I only received instructions from the high command of APLA so as the make the government of the day ungovernable.  I took a decision on my own and that was promulgated by the ANC President, Oliver Tambo.  He also said that we must keep the government of the day ungovernable and the people should arm themself.  That is why I took a decision and decided that I should go ahead with this operation to repossess.
But Mr Malefane, that was an ANC instruction to ANC cadres and activists?
It was not only directed to the ANC soldiers, PAC was working together with other African liberation movements.
Was it a policy of the ANC to repossess or the policy of PAC?
Now how could you do what you have done for the PAC policy on instruction by ANC which if it was not their policy to repossess?

My understanding was that every member of the liberation movement, you would take a decision from any person who has an influential position.  When he spoke he generalised he said that that people should arm themselves so as to make the country ungovernable.  Those were nice words because we were oppressed so when you hear such words, as a human being you will take those words.

I won't take it further Mr Chairman, I think it's a point for argument.  Let's go to page 4?  On page 4 under paragraph 9.4, 10. and other pages I did not mention as well as your evidence in chief, you make mention of a robbery with intention of accumulating capital for the task force.  The word task force goes on and on and on.  What was this task force, what did it consist of?
That was part of the PAC, it's main function was to further the struggle inside the country.

Ja but Mr Malefane, if you were involved in these things, every task force had a commander or a director thereof and members in the task force.  Just tell us who were they, who was the commander of the task force?  PAC had a lot of task forces with commanders and members.
I only know them by their comrade names, I don't know their real names.
Who was the director of operations?
Which operation are you talking about?
Operations carried out by the PAC in the operation units.
He was the director.  Let's leave it there.
He was in the high command.
Have you heard of any task force that was referred to as the Beauty Salon?
There are so many task forces in the PAC.  There are other secrets but you have to reveal ...(intervention)
Sorry Mr Malefane, the question was simple, have you heard of a task force called the Beauty Salon?
Maybe Mr Chairperson just to put it in a unit within the PAC which was code named Beauty Salon within the APLA, you can put it that way, it was also catering for task forces.
Just rephrase your - repeat your question Mr Mpshe.
Mr Malefane, did you know of a unit that was within the PAC and this was also a repossession unit called the Beauty Salon?
No I didn't know that unit.
Did you know any person who was a commander by the name of Maseko?  He is an African.  Mr Chair, when I say African I mean PAC, I'm sorry.
Good, did you know the unit he was responsible for, the task force he was responsible for?
Let's leave it there.  Now I'm going back to my question, the task force you are referring to you, which one is it, who was it's commander?
He was a member of that task force.
And what was the code name of that task force?
He tell me about it's name but he was the commander of that task force.

Now turn to page 9, paginated Mr Chair.  This is the letter you forwarded to TRC when responding to it's questions.  I'm interested in paragraph I think one but let me read the whole thing.  That's where you say, where you mention the people with whom you operated, Bonginkosi Mchunu, Johannes Mkhize, Eric Williams, Bango Ngubane, David Nene, then you say their addresses all of them are at Johannesburg Medium C prison.  Do you see that?

Then you continue saying
"the rest of them they don't belong to any political organisation."
Now if this operation was PAC task force operation, repossessing, how do you involve people who are not members of the PAC in a PAC operation?
I took the decision and these people didn't know what we are going to do at that place, they didn't know why I'm going to repossess that mine.  They were not supposed to know.

You haven't answered my question, I will repeat it for you.  How do you involve non-members in an organisation, in the operation of an organisation because it is PAC organisation, it should have been seen to have found that people who have operated therein were members of that task force or members of APLA.  Now all these were non-members all of them, how do you do that?

I went to Chris Msimeni Langa to ask for money and then he said to me he won't have money for more.  He further said to me that he will introduce me to other people who will accompany me to go and deposit this money.  He then introduced me to David Nene and others.
Who was Chris Langa, what position did he hold?
Chris Langa was a member of the MK.
Did he hold any position of leadership?
No Chairperson, he was not in the leadership.
So he was an ANC cadre, not PAC.
Did Chris Langa know that the operation you want to do you were doing for the purposes of PAC?
And he's the one who took you to non-members either to ANC nor to PAC?
Mr Malefane, didn't you find it funny that you were introduced to people who were non-members of PAC for a PAC operation.  Didn't you find that dangerous?
That did not surprise me because I trusted Chris Langa, we grew up together, he knew all my activities.

Mr Mpshe, would this be a convenient time for the adjournment?  I see it's now past 11 o'clock, we'll have a short tea adjournment.
COMMITTEE ADJOURNS
ON RESUMPTION
Mr Chairperson can I just be afforded one minutes to look at my notes quickly?
(continues) Mr Malefane, just one last question on the leadership of PAC and perhaps APLA in particular.  Do you know a person by the code name of Happy?  Happy.
Do you know a person by the code name of Oumajas?
Do you know a person called Letlape Mpashlele?
Good.  What was his position in the leadership of PAC?

He was a high commander or he is a high commander.  I am talking under correction, you have asked me this question previously regarding his position.  I do know him but it's just that I cannot recall precisely what his actual position is.
Have you met him before?  Yes I have sir.
Good.  If I tell you that he was actually the person in charge of units, repossessing units, what would you say?
Yes I would agree with you on that.
Good, did you ever have any talk with him about this operation of the high commander of such operations?
No, but regarding this operation I never got in contact with him.

Thank you Mr Chairman, that will be all.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MPSHE
Thank you Mr Mpshe.  Mr Mbandanzayo, do you have any re-examination?

Thank you.  Advocate Bosman, do you have any questions to ask the witness?
ADV. BOSMAN: Thank you Chairperson.
	When you were in prison for the first repossession exercise which you mentioned later on, did you maintain any contact with the PAC in Lesotho or within the country at all?

Yes I had contact.
ADV. BOSMAN: With whom did you have this contact?

It was Mofokeng.
ADV. BOSMAN: Now who was Mofokeng?

He was a PAC member.
ADV. BOSMAN: And what was the nature of the contact, what information did you exchange?

He is the one who persuaded me to escape from prison and should I manage, I should leave for Lesotho.
ADV. BOSMAN: Once or twice you made mention of people knowing about your activities and you telling people about your activities.  You testified that Mabena, when you spoke to him at the welcome party, that he knew of your activities.  What were these activities that he knew about?

The assistance that I gave the youth to leave the country and also financial assistance when they needed.
ADV. BOSMAN: How many times did you render financial assistance and where did the money come from?

My grandfather was a taxi owner and therefore he assisted me.  It was finance that we got from his taxi business.
ADV. BOSMAN: So it was never finance coming from any repossession activities?

No.
ADV. BOSMAN: Could you just look at your statement on page 17 of the bundle.  This was part of a statement or confession made to Lieutenant Radley.  About the middle of the page and you are there referring to Eric Ntani.  It reads
"Eric was daar"  ...(intervention)
I don't know, do the interpreters need this to be read in Afrikaans or in English?
We prefer it to be read in English please.

Thank you, so Advocate Bosman will render her own interpretation into English for purposes of translation into Sesotho.
ADV. BOSMAN:	"Eric was there, he then told me that I must go with him to a mine at Stilfontein.  Eric was selling clothes there.  He also said that the truck from Fidelity Guards would bring money to the mine."
Do you have that?

Yes ma'am.
ADV. BOSMAN: Is this factually correct, is this what happened that you went to Eric's shop and Eric told you that you must accompany him to a mine at Stilfontein?

No that is not correct.
ADV. BOSMAN: Then why did you say this then?

I was under pressure at that time.
ADV. BOSMAN: But why did you particularly want to implicate Eric then as being the originator of the idea to go to Stilfontein?  I just don't understand it.  Why , if you were under pressure and I accept you were probably under pressure because you were with the police, why did you think up this about Eric in particular and implicate him as the originator of the idea?

I was trying to safeguard myself from the policeman's torture and I decided to tell a lie.
ADV. BOSMAN: But why Eric in particular, why did you decide on Eric?

It was just instantaneous, I was being tortured.
ADV. BOSMAN: Right, then you said during your evidence - just bear with me for a moment - that there were people involved in the operation who were not members of the PAC and that these people were not supposed to know what the exercise was about.  What did you tell them, these people who were not supposed to know?

I'm not the one who informed them or recruited them, it's Chris who approached them because I approached Chris and he approached them.
ADV. BOSMAN: Didn't you have any discussions with them at all, didn't you tell them what was in it for them, whether they would share in the proceeds and how?

Yes I told them about their role to play in there.
ADV. BOSMAN: What did you tell them?

I told them that should we get the money we will share it.
ADV. BOSMAN: Did you discuss the basis on which it would be shared?

Yes I did.
ADV. BOSMAN: How did you intend sharing it?

Yes equal shares.
ADV. BOSMAN: Would this not have to a large extent defeated the object of the exercise and that is to really put APLA in money?

No.
ADV. BOSMAN: I don't want to take it too far but surely if half the money or more than half of the money would have gone to people who were not even APLA members, this would certainly have been to the prejudice of APLA if this exercise was intended?   Seven eights, there was very little in the whole exercise for APLA if this was going to be the manner in which you would share.  Do you agree?

I think what Advocate Bosman is saying, there were eight of you, if it was equal shares your share would go to APLA, that would be one eighth of the loot, seven eighths would go to other people who were not members of the movement.

That is correct, sir.
ADV. BOSMAN: Did you sort of think this through at the time, think about it?

Yes I did.  I thought thoroughly about it.
ADV. BOSMAN: Didn't it worry you.

No it did not worry me because I would give people an amount of R2 - R3000 whenever they wanted to leave the country and I'd already calculated out that the money will be sufficient, the money we were going to get there.
ADV. BOSMAN: How would have calculated that, did you know how much money was going to be in the security van?

We went to the mines and enquired from the employees as to how do they earn and how many are they per day and this led me to realise that there would be sufficient money at that time.
ADV. BOSMAN: Oh I see so it was the payroll that you were going to get hold of, it was the payroll for the mine that was being transported?
Yes, just sorry before I ask Advocate Motata, I see from the charge sheet on page 48 that the amount stolen was R7220,00 so if you were successful and got away with it, you would have got about R950?
Yes of course it is small change.

Advocate Motata do you have any questions to ask?
ADV. MOTATA: Yes about two Chairperson, thank you.
	Malefane, at the welcome party when you met Mabena and he requested you to give him money and a vehicle, after the getting the money where were you supposed to meet him?

He was supposed to meet me at my home.
ADV. MOTATA: Now you decided to repossess on the 15th July.  When was he supposed to come to your home?

I was going to notify him and ask him to come through.
ADV. MOTATA: When you met at Mothopeng's place did you know where he lived, that is Mabena?

Yes he told me where he was staying.
ADV. MOTATA: From a question from a colleague of the panel here you said you had asked the mine employees how much they earned, that is per day and this Fidelity Guard van was to bring in the payroll, did I understand you correctly?

That is correct, sir.
ADV. MOTATA: And in your evidence you said that, to ask that you went there about twice to reconnoitre the place, do you recall that?  That is to Stilfontein mine.

That is correct, sir.
ADV. MOTATA: Now in asking these people, how many people did you ask or how many employees were there at the Stilfontein mine?

It was quite a number of people.
ADV. MOTATA: Please assist us because you mentioned here that prior to this incident you had assisted people, the youth in particular and you had given about R3000.  Now for you to decide that you were going to repossess money brought in by the Fidelity Guards, you must have had a figure in mind because you had to share equally, that is one eighth per person, you get that?  And now to repossess how much did you expect to repossess that would assist the PAC?

I expected a lot of money, far more than the figure that's stated here.
ADV. MOTATA: Were you told that it's money to pay approximately how many people, a million, a thousand people and how much would a person as you had found out would have earned had the money reached timeously?

They do not earn equal wages.
ADV. MOTATA: Yes that we do understand but you had an occasion to ask the people around, then you formulated the idea that you should repossess, would I be wrong in so assuming?  Because want I want from you Mr Malefane, is for you to assist us, approximately how much was one person even if there were not earning equally, was one person earning at Stilfontein mine?

Some were earning R500, R600 onwards.
ADV. MOTATA: Now you had a figure in mind, did you make elaborate arrangements by reconnaissance about this security van, the Fidelity Guard van?  How much, how you were going to ambush and repossess the money they were carrying?

That is correct, sir.
ADV. MOTATA: When was that done because you have only told us about your visitation to the mine on two occasions only, you haven't told us this far about the Fidelity Guard van.  What did you do and when?

Firstly, we went in the morning and we saw it and saw where it parks and secondly we saw where it parks again.  On both occasions we saw the van and where it parks, that's how we reconnoitred the place as far as the van is concerned.
ADV. MOTATA: Was it before the visitation and the general enquiries from the mine workers or after you had done that?

As soon as the van had left we went around to talk to the people, as soon as it had left we would go and enquire around from the people.
ADV. MOTATA: Were these mine workers paid weekly, fortnightly or monthly?

Fortnightly.  They just get paid daily but when we went there it was a fortnight.
ADV. MOTATA: When you did you not come to realise that some were paid on a daily basis?

I asked around.
ADV. MOTATA: And when you spoke to the mine workers to determine the amount that would be brought, did you speak to people who were being paid fortnightly?

The one person told me that he was going get paid today, the other one said the following day and the other one said he would be getting the money on the fortnight.
ADV. MOTATA: Now how did you determine that on the 15th July the number of people would be paid that would have been fortnightly, how did you determine the number?

I noticed that when we went there on the 15th the people were getting paid so therefore during our visit we noticed that every fortnight these people get paid and the van arrives.
ADV. MOTATA: Assist me here, you say there was Mchunu, Mkhize, Williams, Ngubane, Nene.  Then you say the rest of them they don't belong to any political organisation, when you say that are you referring to the names I've just mentioned?

Yes I'm referring to Aaron and Eric Ntani.
ADV. MOTATA: In other words, the names you haven't mentioned here are the ones you said didn't belong to any organisation because you have mentioned five if you can have regard to page 9 of the papers?

At that time I did not know that the ones I've mentioned here on this page are belonging to a political group or not.  All seven, I was not aware of their political affiliation.
ADV. MOTATA: Mr Malefane, the incident of repossession was on the 15th July 1991, you completed your form, your application form on the 3rd October 1996, if you have regard to page 3 of the papers before you.  Do you see that?

Yes sir.
ADV. MOTATA: My question then is, when did you know then that the others, the seven, belonged to which organisation, liberation movement or did not belong to any?
